title: 40mm E3D fan duct and mount piece for Marty Rice's direct drive extruder

description.text:
Thing name says it all!
I redesigned the hotend small clamp piece in Marty's direct drive extruder, adding a hinge to attach the fan duct.
The fan duct is my own design, it's far from perfect but does the job.
OpenSCAD sources are included for both the fan duct and the clamp piece, so they can be remixed at will.

A 16mm or 20mm M3 bolt and nut are required for the hinge, and a few more M3 bolts and nuts for the fan and optional fan guard.  
The 40mm 12V fan is commonly available and provides more than adequate cooling for the E3D aluminum body. Note that this is not a layer fan, it should be spinning all the time the printer is powered on (i.e. connect it directly to the power supply +12V output, NOT to the RAMPS fan output).

I don't know if this should be considered a derivative of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:591 or not. It was inspired by it but I started from scratch because I wanted to do it in openscad.
You can adjust the size and tweak the dimensions of the various parts of the lego in the openscad file.
There are probably bugs, it's a work in progress.
A real lego snaps into the bottom pretty well, not as well on top.

The script defines a module called block(width,length,height,axle_hole,reinforcement)
The width and length defines how long and wide the block is (surprise!).  They are defined as the number of knobs in that direction, not the actual length in mm.
The height is a multiple of the standard height of a brick.
The axle_hole variable adds holes to the top of the brick to fit standard lego axles through.  They may only fit partway through unless your printer can handle really thin walls.
The reinforcement variable adds ribs across the brick to reinforce it (which also makes it print nicer because it gives the bot somewhere to traverse between the posts on the underside of the brick without leaving strings everywhere)

title: S4 mini holder for car vents - Volkswagen CC ou Golf

description.text: As I use Samsung S4 mini as navigation system, I built this holder based on other phone models holders and vent fixings.

Print S4 mini crad and 2 vent mounts (one mount and the same with R)
Attach Vent mounts to Crad using contact glue or with screws.
I use this holder for more than one year and it doesn't damage vents or leaves marks on the dashboard. Phone never went off crad.
I prefer to attach vent mounts to crad using screws because it makes it easier to unmount holder from vents, especially if space between vents is small.
I used fill in rate of 60% for vent mounts
For crad, I print with raft as printing is a quite long process. I prefer vent mounts "car_vent_mountLargeI" and "car_vent_mountLargeIR" because it brings more angle view to driver. Please note this was made for left hand drive vehicles,so mirror it if you have right hand drive car.

The Polyalphabetic Substitution Cipher Slide Rule.  This is a slide rule to assist with the ciphering and deciphering of polyalphabetically enciphered messages.  With it, you can learn a bit about how slide rules work and a bit about crypto at the same time!  It also has some added features that let you begin exploring strong crypto.

You can make two PSRs out of one piece of 12"x12" material.  There's no waste leftover with this design!
The PSR is essentially three pieces, the slide, the body and the indicator.  The body consists of a top and bottom stator which cradle the slide.  The indicator goes on top of the body and slide.
Glue the top row of letters (top stator) and the bottom row of numbers (bottom stator) to the body.  Then glue together the indicator.  The indicator should slide over the base.  VoilÃ !  Now get to ciphering!
The PDF should help make things clearer.

description.text: Ampelmann avec trou à la verticale

A clock face based on 9's taking a standard clock mechanism.
Printed in one piece from 2 files with a change of filament colour.
Numbers project about 1.5mm from face. A second version of the base has a sacrificial rim to allow a skirt to be used on the face. See instructions. A second version of the face has tick marks on the hours.

I split this into two parts to make changing filament straightforward.  
The first part is just the cylindrical base. It is best to slice this so the motors, heaters are left on, and just moved to a parking position.   
Then change the filament and make sure it is extruding the new colour OK. Reset current z-axis position to 0 (e.g G92 Z0) so that next print starts from current height.  
Then print clockface. The rim is printed first which gets the filament going without a skirt.   
The base is just a very simple OPENSCAD. The face was an image, converted to svg in Inkscape and then extruded in Blender.  
Originally I printed both bits without a skirt to avoid the face overlay printing a skirt into fresh air. This meant the first part of the face rim sometimes didn't get going immediately. THis didn't really matter too much.  
A better technique which I am now using is to add a sacrificial rim onto the base. With this method I print the base without a skirt and it has a 1mm rim spaced out by 1mm from the main base. The face can now be printed with a 1.5mm skirt which goes on top of the rim and the filament is flowing nicely before the main print starts. The rim is simply discarded after removing the print.

description.text: Sometime we need to put some tools for 3D printer. We make a tool holder for that!
Just printe with 30% infill.
Box designed for my wife to store Essential Oils collection.   This is a 4 x 4 compartment box

You will need to rotate the STL files such that the bottom of the box and top of the lid are oriented on the build surface. This is a large build. I used ABS plastic on a raft. To ensure that the layers remained laminated I shielded the build area with a poster board shield (Airwolf 3D XL with no enclosure). As an aside, Rev - did not have the outer columns and used lower infill -- it cracked and delaminated severely. The rounded edges, higher infill, and higher filament temperature seems to have resolved the cracking issue. Other Parameters:
Filament Temperature: 250 C
Bed Temperature: 120 C
Layer height: 0.2
Infill: 80% You will very likely need to sand the inside edges of the top and outside of the bottom mating area to the top to get a good sliding fit. The design is zero-clearance, so required clearance will need to be made.

both practical and novel. Works with all cables, from iPhones and
speakers to general power cables. Store your cables neatly and
always have them at the right length, of course with many audio
cables you should always fully unwind when in use to avoid
distortion. If the sizes provided don’t fit quite right then just scale
them to the custom size you need. All parts are designed to be printed without support and snap
together so you can always reopen them to change the cable or
mix and match colors. Place your cable in the slot of the spool,
snap the casing around it and turn it from the grip in the back to
wind up the cable. To store it neatly you can pull the cable through
the slot in the spool to create a loop and push the ends though, as
shown in the photo. To unwind you can just pull either end of the
cable, which make the logo spin or record “play”.

Here is a ghostly record player spool holder. As the spool turns out it spins the top "record" looking like the needle is playing the record. The base is all the functioning buttons of a record player. As a final touch I placed the ghostly symbol on the top. I am not able to test this out as I don't have a printer but I have a mechanical background so all the measurements and threads are accurate. It was designed to be printer friendly so all angles come into each other so there is no need for supports. When printing the needle flip it on its back so the needle is pointing upwards for ease of printing.
Hope you enjoy it.

Here is another redneck linear with a little more power. Uses standard continuous rotation Servo, 1/4-20 all thread and has bearings on the spool. Should have many applications in robotics and home automation.
This linear has a one to one gear ratio and has travel of .050 inches per servo rotation. That give a travel of about 2.7 inches per minute with the Pololu 1248 (SpringRC SM-S4303R, Jameco 2128201 $13.95) continuous rotation servo. I do not have one, so have not tried it but, Parallax makes a high speed CR servo that is way faster (180 RPM), that would make the linear travel 9" per minute (Parallax 900-00008).
This design uses standard 1/4-20 nuts inside the spool to move the all thread rod. Uses two 18x12x4mm RC car/truck bearings on the spool. Yoke holds the rod fixed with a 1/4-20 nut, the gear and motor move the all threaded rod. Uses #4 sheet metal screws for fasteners and #6 machine screws for yoke pins.
Since continuous rotation servos work on speed and time this type of linear would need micro switch cut off if traveling long distance and ending up in an exact spot.
The servo gear is for standard 25T Futaba spline. If you need other servo spline sizes let me know.
Still having trouble with threads, you will have drill to .200" and run a 1/4-20 tap in the yoke for threads.

Do you need to improve your cable management of your sound system ? Fortunately there is the Ghostly's family !!! Ghostly's family is compose by multiple pieces to help you to manage your sound system. Differents combos are possible and let you print what is best for your needs. Here is a quick and non-limiting summary of fonctions Ghostly family may handle for you :
  • Cable hidind
  • Cable reel (both cable reel may be contained between the base and the shell)
  • Antena hiding for wireless sound system
  • Remote holder
    ...
    • Easly printable with different materials to match with your interior. Let you enjoy your sound system with the Ghostly's family.

Shell + base : Base is made to improve hiding cable and give an impression levitation of Ghostly. Three different shell are disponible, each one is made to fit to different needs.  
Cable reel : To made a cable reel you need two pieces you can put together by clips. The form of the cable reel is made for a perfect winding of your cable. Two different size are disponible. You can use the cable reel independently from other pieces or you can combine it. The large reel is made to be contained once between base and shell, tow small reel fit in and let you hide multiple device cable into one shell. (a new version coming soon with a hole in the middle to combine with the antenna hider.)

I made the holes 2 mm but I may need to increase to 3 mm... Still a work in progress but works with regular cleaning :)

It has an outer diameter of 70mm and an internal diameter of 43mm.
The outer rim is 1 mm thick, overall it is 6mm thick
The holes are 2 mm.
This is my first design...
Maybe some adjustments are necessary...
I will update after some testing :)

title: Vash Revolver
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Remixed the awesome Trigun prop from Dan0nator (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:251565) and adjusted it to fit an UP! mini. Added:

  • Split the barrel to fit on the build plate (added alignment peg from Emmets awesome gears (www.thingiverse.com/thing:50716)

  • Fattened the grip to make it more comfortable. Also made it hollow (i filled it with concrete and then sealed it to give weight)

  • Added a cutout in the frame and barrel to glue a magnet (makes an AWESOME snap when they come together and keeps it from opening by itself)

  • redesigned the cylinder to allow the rounds to stay securely in

title: Star Wars The Force Awakens - BB-8 Ball Droid

description.text:
ANNOUNCEMENT!! The files for this model have been removed from this page, from now on the files can downloaded for free from www.MyMiniFactory.com. This page will be left for legacy purposes and I will still answer questions if posted. From now on, all my future projects will feature exclusively on www.MyMiniFactory.com.
My profile page is https://www.myminifactory.com/users/lilykill. Sorry for any inconvenience.

This is the droid your looking for. Just seen the trailer for episode 7 and thought this droid looked awesome. I still need to add more details but I just wanted to try and get the model done ASAP but cant wait to finish it when I get more details. The model is 1:1 scale with the head being roughly being the same diameter as R2's. But this can be changed later when we know more about the droid. Follow me on twitter @ https://twitter.com/lilykill1, and instagram @ https://instagram.com/lilykill1/ and facebook @ https://www.facebook.com/Lilykill-253119598353137/ where you can stay up-to-date on my current projects and releases. If interested, join my group @ http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/design-to-print/topics where I aim to help anybody with anything I can with modeling or complex assembly like this design. Edit:- 30/11/14
Just finished the model to the best reference images I have. Enjoy. Edit:- 02/12/14
Two piece models added. Edit:- 02/12/14
head and body without stub end and insert added.
hollow versions of body and head added. Edit:- 03/12/14
Neck joint strengthened on single part STL Edit:- 22/04/15
SolidWorks model added

remixed_from.title: CR123A / 16340 Lithium Cell Charger Using TP4056

description.text:
Charge a 18650 battery using the cheap TP4056 circuit boards available on ebay.  
There are holes in the cradle to allow a cable or paperclip to go through. This gives more stability and stops the paperclip from moving.  There are also grooves to hold them in as well.  
Inspired by Kauz's charger for the CR123A battery.

This is some simple feet for a Printrbot Simple Metal (1403). I stuck on 1/2 inch rubber bumpers on the bottom of them to help with vibrations. The circle is 15mm in diameters in 8mm tall with a 2mm line to fit it Printrbot Simple Metal.

Holes and nut-traps in footed vertexes to accommodate screws for leveling. 3 flavors:
M8 & M4
5/16" & M4
5/16" & 6-32 untested For the M4 variants, I'd recommend using M4 rosette thumb screws with the leveling cap screws: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5704.

• Print out
  • Insert nut into nut trap
  • Insert screw into rosette thumb screw (optional)
  • Insert screw into vertex
  • Replace footed vertexes with new leveling vertexes
  • Rotate screws to level your Mendel

author: JuanVL

description.text:
A pendant design based on the sigil of the Clayr from Garth Nix's Abhorsen series.  This model can be printed directly or, more interestingly, cast in metal using provided molds.  
The default size is about an inch and a half across and weighs less than 2 ounces when cast.  Almost all parameters are adjustable via the Customizer.

I've provided files to print a whole pendant, a half pendant, and a mold (for casting in the material of your choice). For full directions (with more pictures) see the writeup on my website. Printing a whole pendant
====================
To print a whole pendant in one go, use the Pendant.stl file provided. You'll DEFINITELY need support with it. Printing a half-pendant
==================
To print a half-pendant, print two copies of the PendantHalf.stl file provided. It shouldn't require any support material. Glue or epoxy them together. Casting a pendant
===============
This project is the pilot for a generalized metalcasting method using 3D printed molds. In order to be able to cast directly into a mold, we need to use a special metal, see below. Although I've provided a number of different shapes, I recommend using the projection-shaped molds throughout. The metal we're going to use is a Bismuth-Tin alloy, and is non-toxic. It's not food safe, so don't try to eat it. The particular alloy (which I bought on Amazon) melts at 138C/281F, which should be readily achievable on a stove-top. I elected not to use the oven in case of contamination by fumes - as I mentioned earlier this is NOT food safe. Materials:

• 3D printer & plastic
  • Metal of choice (though I very much encourage you to use the one I recommend)
  • 2+ Clamps
  • A container to melt metal in (chemistry lab quality glass preferred). This container will end up holding the leftover metal after it solidifies - you probably will not be able to use it for anything else.
  • A container to catch melted metal in (again, chemistry lab quality glass preferred)
    • Steps:

• Print the molds. I'm currently using 0.05mm layers, 0.8mm thickness for all dimensions and 8% infill. These settings may need adjustment for your printer - but should provide a good starting point.
  • Clamp the molds together as shown in the third gallery picture.
  • Cool all the molds in the freezer for at minimum 3 hours.
  • Melt the metal. THIS STEP CAN BE DANGEROUS. Always wear safety gear - at a minimum eye protection and gloves that can handle the temperatures. (Oven mitts work wonderfully).
    Any way you can heat it works. Ideally, use a chemistry lab quality glass beaker and a hotplate. If you don't have access to these, I suggest a flat-bottomed Pyrex bowl on the stove, although I've seen it work with ceramics and glass. Stay away from the stove while the metal is heating, in case the container has a flaw that causes a catastrophic failure. If you have an extractor fan of any kind, use it. Finally, DO NOT quench or dip in water the container of metal. Let it cool in its own time.
  • Set up the area around the mold. Raise the mold and clamps up above a container that can catch any spilled metal. Again, use glass or ceramic containers.
  • Pour the melted metal. Pour metal slowly into the funnel until the funnel is about half full and stays there.
    7.Agitate. The mold needs slight agitation as the metal cools. This agitation helps remove any residual air so the metal can fill the entire mold. I found that picking up the molds by the clamps and giving them small shakes for about 30 seconds worked extremely well.
  • Wait. Wait until the metal in the funnel is solid and warm to the touch (rather than hot).
  • Remove the funnel from the other mold parts. Start by removing the clamps. The funnel will be stuck to the two smaller pieces of the mold by a small cylinder of metal. In my experience, twisting the funnel will remove it.
  • Freeze for 3+ hours. This will cause the metal to shrink (and it shrinks more than the plastic) which will make the final part easier to remove.
  • Remove the part from the mold.
    11a. Method 1: The first half is easy to get off - you ought to be able to, with some difficulty, pry half of the mold off. The other half is more complicated. Put your thumbs in the center of the backside, grab the edges with your fingers, and bow the mold as if you were trying to push the metal out from the back. Repeat several dozen times, rotating the mold between attempts. Very quickly you should see all the points and all the keys come loose, so you can bend the mold and they don't bend. Further bends are to loosen the center, which eventually pops out. If needed, freeze the mold again. Make sure the part has somewhere soft to land - I broke several by popping them out onto a hardwood floor.
    11b. Method 2: Cut the metal free. If you don't care about reusing molds, this may be easier. The methodology for cutting the mold is up to you. But be mindful of exposing the metal to heat, if you choose to use a heat-based method.
  • Cut off the nub on the back. Removing the pendant from the mold leaves a metal nub on the back of the pendant. I used a Dremel cutting disk to grind it off, though many methods will work.
  • Hang. Hanging the pendant is another place where you get to choose the methodology. My favored method is to use jeweler's wire by cutting a length, folding it in half and running it through the small hole in the top-most point. Then I bend the two ends back around to the side that now has the loop and solder them together. This way it can be hung on either a continuous chain or a chain with a clasp.
  • Celebrate. You now have a custom pendant! The .scad file should be adaptable to many different shapes. Play around, but expect some difficulty - OpenSCAD doesn't let you query some properties, meaning that you'll have to adjust them manually.
    • Notes

• It has been my experience that the molds do not melt overmuch, and could possibly be reused for multiple castings. However, i haven't tried doing so, mostly because I needed to make design revisions from mold to mold.
  • I also looked at Field's metal, which melts about 62C. Field's metal is a well-known non-toxic alloy, and the one I came across most in my search. However, the cost for this is exorbitant - $100 for 4 ounces. I decided to go with the cheaper but harder to melt metal for pure cost.
  • Any mistakes or the metal left in the funnel can be remelted with the remaining metal in the container for use in other castings. However, do make sure that no plastic makes it into the metal to melt.

I've been 3D printing now for a few years and have collected countless spools of filament. I have my lab/shop in the basement and my joists are exposed. I decided to create this little hanger so I can use cheap 1/2" PVC pipe to hand my spools and other things from the joists. I just use some simple screws and cut a piece of PVC long enough to span the gap.   
I designed it with two screw holes so if you are hanging something pretty heavy you can double up on the screws. Normally, you just use the center hole.  
Works great.
I only print in ABS and for a part like this I used 250 microns and about 75% fill. So far this works well. If you're worried about strength, maybe do 100%.

title: Snowflake Cutter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Have you ever folded up a piece of paper and cut a snowflake out of it? This is the 3D-printing version! Press the "Open in Customizer" button to draw a wedge of your own unique pattern, which will then be mirrored and rotated to make a snowflake ready for downloading and printing. See the green triangle illustrations in the gallery for examples of where to draw in the square to make your snowflake pattern. Please post a "make" if you create your own snowflake! Every one will be different and it will be great to see what they look like. Read more about this design at Hacktastic:
http://mathgrrl.com/hacktastic/2014/11/snowflake-cutter/ SNOWFLAKE UPDATE 2015: This year you can create algorithmically-grown snowflakes from a random seed and use sliding parameters to control the style and form of the design of the snowflakes, at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1159436 =====

This design and all associated pictures and files are licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial Share Alike license. If you want to use designs, images, or files outside of the terms of this license, please email [email protected].

• Press Customizer button.

  • Set size, thickness, and whether or not you want a loop to be included.

  • Press the "Cut" tab.

  • Scroll down and press "Clear" to clear the design.

  • Draw in the Customizer box to make your pattern. The part you draw between "12 o'clock" and "1 o'clock" is what will be used to make the snowflake. For example, see the green triangle in the gallery pictures; the triangle isn't shown in the Customizer so you will have to imagine it when you make your drawing.

  • Save and download your design.

  • Print with no raft at whatever layer height you prefer. Works well on .3mm/low setting.
Don't have a 3D printer, or want something fancy printed for you? You can get custom snowflake earrings and ornaments made with the Snowflake Machine in our print-to-order shop:

title: Pivoting ball joint stand for a phone

description.text: Simple two part stand for holding a phone in landscape view.  Needed a stand to do some "steady" time lapse and slow-mo shots with my phone.

Used OpenSCAD to do the models at the same time. Went through two design revisions before getting something I liked and could print with a Thing-O-Matic. Rafting is highly recommended. You will only need to change two clearly marked variables in the OpenSCAD model to make a stand that will fit your phone:
size: diameter of ball (in mm)
widthOfSlot: how thick your phone is in mm (give +1mm for a nice fit) After printing you may need to trim a side of the inner ball joint to complete the assembly.

title: Spooker Wire Manager #GhostlyVinyl
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
So, we all know that cable management can greatly effect sound quality. And we also know the big things like avoiding ground loops and separating power cables from all of the other cables and we all have pretty and functional doodads that help us in our quest for the 'holy grail' of sound. Then why, in the age of home 3d printing, do so many of my audiophile friends have their speaker wire on Styrofoam cups? Crazy! I made these speaker wire bridges to help their aesthetic (adorned appropriately with Ghostly International's logo) while they search for the right sound.  
I tested 4 iterations of this design all out of ABS and found that it works for other cables and wires as well. If anyone makes it with PLA, please get back to me and let me know of any shortcomings. I'm sure they can be optimized for PLA. Heck, any feedback , improvements or questions would be welcome. Thanks!

description.text: Replacement for Acrylic cover for Solidoodle 2 Electronics section to allow attachment of 40mm cooling fan.

I was experiencing problems with X/Y carriage jumps which mysteriously came and went during the day, most problematic on hot days.  By adding a cooling fan to the electronics this problem has gone away.
Print the model, attach a 40mm fan, and install as a replacement for the acrylic piece.  
I applied power to the Fan from a seperate power supply.

For printing, glass is an ideal surface because it's extremely flat, and stays that way. But custom glass sizes are expensive special orders, while 8x10 plate glass is cheap and easy to purchase. My printers (Replicator and FlashForge) have roughly 6x9 print beds. And it turns out that 8x10 plate glass works perfectly. Unfortunately it's tricky to hold glass larger than the print bed in place, because you have to use large binder clips, and the extruder can run into the clips. And you can only clip down two edges, because the other two edges stick way out. So I've designed these clips that fit on the corners of the print bed, extending it so that it holds standard 8x10 plate glass. The edges of the clips are thin, so you can use small binder clips. There are quite a few similar clips on Thingiverse, which inspired me to design my own. The main difference is that it's Customizable so it's easy to generate clips for different printers with similar designs. And it has thin edges, which allows using small binder clips. Warning: Glass can Break
    • One caveat - $1.99 plate glass is 3/32" thick, so it's not as durable as thicker, more expensive glass. But in my experience, as long as the glass is flat on the print bed or other surface, it's supported and won't break. But if you try to pull prints off of glass while holding it in your hand, it can easily break. So don't do that. You can also get 8x10 sheets of plexiglass, wood, etc., which can be useful to print on, depending on what you're printing with. Z-Adjust
    • You'll probably want to use something like http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:43783 to adjust the Z-stop. The details vary by specific printer. What to print
    • I have a MBI Replicator (original) and a FlashForge Pro, so I have attached STL files for those printers. Print two each of the Left and Right parts. If you use a slicer that generates support, you can use the NoSupport STL files. The other files include support in the design. It's also Customizable, so you can put in measurements for other similar printers.

Instructions
=

  • For the Replicator 1 or FlashForge, print two "Left" and two "Right" clips. The "left" clips will go in the front-left and back-right corners, and the "right" clips will go in the front-right and back-left corners. The long clip arms should stick out the front and back, and the short clip arms should stick out the sides. See the rendering and photo's for examples of how the clips are oriented.

  • Get some 8x10 plate glass, and some small binder clips. You can leave them plain glass, put blue painter's tape, Kapton tape, Tufnell, glue stick, Souave, etc.

  • Unscrew the front-left corner screw. Leave the screw in place, but remove the nut. You'll need a hex screwdriver or Allen key, which likely came with your printer.

  • Place the nut into the 'capture' hole in the bottom of one of the "left" corners.

  • Press the corner up against the screw (with your finger on the nut to hold it into place) so that it fits onto the end of the screw. Tighten the screw until it pulls the clip into place, so the top of the clip is level with the top of the print bed.

  • Repeat for the other three corners.

  • Place a plate of 8x10 glass on the print bed. It should fit between the clips, with minimal 'wiggle' room. Clip the front edges with small binder clips.

  • Tighten down the adjustments for the print bed, and level the print bed as usual.
    • Customizer

  • If you have a different, similar printer, you can use Customizer to adjust the print bed size (left-right, front-back, and thickness) and screw position and size to generate clips that fit your printer.

    • Souave

  • For printing PLA, my best results are using Souave Extreme Hold hairspray, sprayed (and dried) three times, so the coating is quit smooth and solid, giving dozens of prints on a plate before it needs to be re-coated. Wood Glue also works extremely well, applied with a squeegee. Because 8x10 plate glass is cheap and easily available at the hardware store, I prepped a dozen sheets of plate glass, so I always have plenty to print on, and can easily swap between print beds to suit PLA, ABS and Nylon.

comments.text:
Nice design. I made my own, but now see some flaws. Will try this one. Ilike to print on glass, because it's flat and easy to use. No more tape to apply and remove. First I used spray to get PLA to stick, but the spray leads to ugly stains on the surface of the printed part. So I tried to get the PLA stick without spray by raising the bed temperature from 60C to 80C and that works pretty well. Got this idea, because my PETG sticks on glass without anything else at 90° bed temperature, so tried the same for PLA with slightly lower temp. It works.
So I like glass and as there are those cheap glass frames for fotos, it is easy and cheap to get. After printing, I remove it from the printbed and put it on the (wooden?) back that came with the foto frame. There it can cool down and after a few minutes, I can remove the parts without using a tool and with now force. You cann hear some cracking sound when it cools down and tzhat is the sound of the plastic getting of the glass. Did not try that for ABS so far, but works well for PETG and PLA.
For ABS you probably need hairspray, but hairspray can easily be reomoved with warm water. Just put the glass into a tray with some water and let it soak for half an hour. Then you can just rinse it off (help with a cloth). Also works without soaking time, but then you need more force with the cloth.

description.text: This is the C7 logo I created in school using our IDEAS program. The XYZWare sliced the checkered portion out in that empty indent on the left side. There usually is a 1/16" extruded effect in there to make the checkered look. This was printed out on my Da Vinci 1.0 and pre calibration. I have now re-calibrated the printer and I'll print out a better example and post the picture afterwards. Enjoy!

I believe the white one is printed in .2 or .3 mm layers with a horribly calibrated printer. Since then I have recalibrated and printed in .1 to make a really great result which is the black one. The red logo is the one printed out at school with their MakerBot Z18 at .1 mm using PLA whereas my prints are ABS. The density can be anything you want.

I don't know about you, but I LOVE IT when I'm inserting the Y-axis rods into my Flashforge Creator and the flanged 5x10x4 bearings get pushed in or better yet, fall off the rod and into the frame. Bonus points for when they fall into the little diagonal hole and then they rest on top of the motherboard. My personal favorite is when they dislodge during a print and ruin everything. I got tired of this nonsense and designed this little sanity-saver. It's a remix of dssguy1's retainer for non-flanged bearings. In order to use it, you need to reverse the stock position of the four flanged bearings and make sure the flange is located on the outside of the frame. When drilling the two holes for the two M3 bolts in each corner, heed this advice from dssguy1: "Word to the wise, when you drill through your case, use a small drill bit first and then a larger one at high speed so you don't damage your ply-wood. You can also try to butt up a piece of wood on the inside of the drilled area and it will stop any splintering." Thanks to dssguy1 for the inspiration and his kindness.

description.text: Double Thickness Quadcopter Bottom Plate.
STL model to replicate your AD595/AD597 pcb support

I purchased the Quanum Goggles but wanted the ability to be able to take them apart and clean them or change the magnifying lens. I looked around to see if anyone designed anything but did not find one so I designed this in SketchUp. Worked out real nice.

I designed this to use M3.5 14mm metric button head screws. On the goggles, I used a 13/37 drill bit to drill a hole to fit the stud pieces in to each half on the side. Both in front and behind the slide area. (PLEAS, ALWAYS CHECK YOUR WORK TWICE BEFORE YOU DRILL OR CUT!) ( I also do not take any responsibility it you damage your goggles.) Once I am happy with the holes, I epoxy the studs in and let dry. I used a 7/64 drill bit to clean the holes in the studs so the M3 screws can screw in cleanly. Once the epoxy is dry, then screw together with the strap parts for both the front and back. Once again, use the 7/64 drill bit to clean the  holes on the "screw pad with strap clamp" parts. Attach the clamp head with the M3 screws and place the strap between the two parts. Tighten the screws and you are all done. Looking at the pictures I posted should help if you have any questions. This setup worked out very nice for my goggles. Enjoy.

hi, thanks for the remix what kind of glue worrks with PLA? I am having a horrible time with my hands. I can not get the moveable fingers to stay on. I have decisded to drill thru and the glue the fingers to a rod :o)
Jessie
comments.author: Jessie49

comments.text: I use Methylene Chloride.  Wear gloves and don't get any on your fingers, also keep in an airtight container.. but it bonds PLA like magic, it works even better than acetone on ABS..
comments.author: Jessie49

comments.text: Superglue works you just have to be careful not to use too much or it takes too long to set. I use a toothpick and run a drop down it to help control how much gets on the parts. Just let a small drop run down to the tip and if it's too much just tap it to get off the excess. On really small parts you may want to glue a larger piece with the toothpick and then use the left over on the tip to put a dot on the small part(s) Air needs to get to the surfaces being bonded for the glue to set and that can't happen if the area is "flooded" with glue. Superglue is a lot like 3D printing in that you MUST use a series of thin layers and build it up if you want to make a thick layer. Less is more when it comes to superglue and most people try to use way too much

description.text: A set of 3 Icicles to create a neopixel wonderland. http://youtu.be/_0oziTATzxo They fit my Washing up bottle Neopixel holder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:570549 and come in 3 sizes, each holding a breadboard friendly Neopixel (http://www.adafruit.com/products/1312). They look glorious printed in Glacial Blue PLA from Fabidashery. http://www.faberdashery.co.uk/products-page/print-materials/glacial-blue/

The thread isn't perfect, but they work well enough.  The largest seems to generate some weird gcode, but they've printed cleanly.  They take 90-120 mins each - a set of 15 plus caps took most of a 100m roll of filament.  
The cut-out arches are simply to save plastic and time - the LED shines where the solid icicle begins.  I've probably made them a little too delicate for some purposes, but I was against the clock when designing and printing them.  
The Washup caps have a loop to thread string for support - see their page on Thingverse for more details.

comments.text: Somehow there is always a bright line of light down the centre of each icicle when they are lit.  I guerss it is a combination of the plastic's translucency and the optics inherent with 3d print

description.text: The heavy tank IS-1 was designed with thick armour to counter the German 88 mm guns, and carried a main gun that was capable of defeating the German Tiger and Panther tanks. It was mainly a breakthrough tank, firing a heavy high-explosive shell that was useful against entrenchments and bunkers. The IS-1 was put into service in April 1944, and was used as a spearhead in the Battle of Berlin by the Red Army in the final stage of the war. The IS-85 (Object 237) prototype was initially accepted for production as the IS-1 heavy tank and first deliveries were made in October 1943. Production ended in January 1944.

author: Winne

description.text: (taken from my blog post: http://matz-make.posterous.com/whuzzat) It's funny how something that started out as a simple toy replacement turned into... Whuzzat? My son loves Ben 10, and has that Omnitrix toy that's a huge watch that's impossible for a kid to put on himself. My goal was to create something that made him feel sort of like Ben Tennison, but also something he could put on himself. Thus, I came up with this design. I made it with OpenSCAD because I wasn't sure if I would get the dimensions correct, or if I'd need to make small changes to make the wristband fit more comfortably. I modeled it in such a way that I could specify the wrist width and thickness, since these are pretty easy measurements to take. Then of course, you would want to specify the thickness of the band, as well as its length. There also needs to be an opening on one side in order to put on the band. With those parameters, I created Whuzzat. By now you're probably wondering how a Ben 10 wannabe toy could be called something like Whuzzat. Well, when I thought about this design, it was more than just a simple Omnitrix. It was also a simple bracelet that you can print for your daughter. Using tricks from Tony Buser's parametric nametag (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2055), or the the OpenSCAD code for my Parametric Cup Name Tag (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5309), you can put a name on the bracelet! My wife uses a hook in the closet to hold wet towels on a hanger if there isn't enough room on a towel bar. Well, by modifying the parameters for the Whuzzat, you can have one, too! How about Halloween decorations? Narrow the "wrist thickness", lengthen the "wrist width", thicken the band, and narrow the "opening width", then print a bunch of Whuzzats in black, and you have a chain! What about cable organization? Why buy an expensive cable track, when you can print a few Whuzzats that fit inside of each other? Screw the smaller one to your desk, then snap the larger one over it! It's amazing how such a simple design can be used in so many different ways. Can you think of any others? If so, please post your derivatives!

There are only five parameters that you need to adjust to make your very own Whuzzat:
  • wrist_width = how wide your "wrist" is
  • wrist_thickness = how thick your "wrist" is
  • band_width = how wide the band should be. Think of it like a watch band.
  • band_thickness = how thick you want the wall of the band to be.
  • opening_width = how large of an opening you want in one side to fit something into the Whuzzat.
    • As you can see from the pictures, there are a lot of things you can do with this! Take the code, play with it, and see if you can make something else out of it! For example, draw another Whuzzat, flip it around, and then you have a double sided hook!

description.text:
now you can print a cartridge and ammo to your nerf in dual extrusion.
I recommend you to print the ammo with flexible filament.

I needed a possibility to present my firearms / airsoft guns without having them somewhere in a tray or laying around on the ground.  
So I made this little thing which fits into the magwell of original AR 15s / M4 based systems and Systema PTW Airsoft Guns including clones (on the picture is an A&K) or V2 Gearbox based M4 Airsoft Guns.  
The stand actually holds on the bottom surface of the magazine catch. So do not misplace it - otherwhise it goes into the magwell completly.  
Hope you like it - now you can present your weapon on a table or in your gear room.
Made with 20% infill and layer thickness of 0,2 with ABS plastic. Without rafts or support structures. Pretty easy to print as long as your heat bed is aligned properly.

comments.text:
Fits my Bushmaster Carbon-15 magwell with a little 'slop'. I know my Hictop sizing is on the money since parts I print for it match screw-holes dead on.
That slop means the top of the stand doesn't catch on the magazine stop inside the mag-well and goes through fully to the bolt carrier.
If it did hit the stop inside correctly it would still be a little short.
I'm going to try printing at X & Y of 105%, and Z of 175% to make it tall enough to clear the pistol grip and fore grip.

title: OpenSCAD Kate Snippets - Code completion and more

description.text:
Update 2017/8: 
I added some more snippets :-)
This snippets will allow for easy code completion by offering itself when you type and press CTR+SPACEBAR in Kate.  
Its an early version, there is more possible with scripts and stuff but I only use these functions for now.  
There is also a icon file and Settings for Kate and a screenshot how to create a new filetype for .scad
If you want, improve it and write me a note. Then i will update this version with the better one :-)  
Thanks and have fun creating stuff more easily :-)

Install the files in the directories written in the Readme files.
See the Settings Screenshots for the Kate settings.
You have to create a filetype for .scad files. This is easy! Also maybe you need to enable the "Snippets tool view" pluigin in the settings of Kate. Then click into the plugin-snippets-bar and click on "Add Repository" Then search for OpenSCAD. Have fun. These instructions work on KDE 5.

description.text: Bench block for gunsmithing.
Bench block for gunsmithing. Print in a material with a high impact resistance with high or 100% infill.

comments.text: I printed it with PLA using a Hatchbox Alpha:  5 layers top and bottom and 4 on the sides with 30% infill.  That took over 6 hours and weighs 116 grams. .  If it doesn't take the pounding I'll try it with ABS...But I think it will be fine.  If you get good fusion between the layers top and bottom I think the models deal with impact a little better.  The worst areas for fusion on mine are the underside channels where there were supports.  The next (?) time I make one I think I'll flip it upside down so there will be far less support material (and save on printing time and filament).
